content: I am running a "find" command to gather all folders and files, and outputting the result into a file named "files_and_folders". However, I am getting "permission denied" messages. How can I exclude these messages from the output? Also, is it possible to direct the permission levels to the "files_and_folders" file, while hiding the errors?

When you run the `find` command and encounter "permission denied" messages, it's because the command doesn't have the necessary permissions to access certain directories or files. To exclude these error messages from the output, you can redirect the standard error (stderr) to `/dev/null`. Here's how you can do that:

```bash
find /path/to/search -type f -o -type d > files_and_folders 2>/dev/null
```

In this command:
- `2>/dev/null` redirects the standard error stream to `/dev/null`, effectively discarding it, so you won't see "permission denied" messages.

If you want to log the permissions of the files and folders into the `files_and_folders` file, you can use the `-ls` option with `find`, which provides detailed information including permissions:

```bash
find /path/to/search -ls > files_and_folders 2>/dev/null
```

This will list files and directories with their details, including permissions, and redirect any error messages to `/dev/null` so they're not included in `files_and_folders`.

If you want to separate the permission errors into a different file, you can redirect stderr to a different file:

```bash
find /path/to/search -ls > files_and_folders 2> permission_errors.log
```

This command will save the detailed list with permissions to `files_and_folders` and any "permission denied" errors to `permission_errors.log`.
